{{refimprove|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox Radio Show | class = | show_name = The Howard Stern Wrap-Up Show | image = The wrap up show logo.jpg | imagesize = 220px |format = [[Talk show]], [[Entertainment]] |runtime = ~1 hour |language = English |home_station = [[Howard 100 and Howard 101|Howard 100]] | starring = [[Jon Hein]]
[[Gary Dell'Abate]] | opentheme = "[[Remedy (The Black Crowes song)|Remedy]]" by [[The Black Crowes]] | endtheme = "Remedy" or
"[[Fuckin' in the Bushes]]" by [[Oasis (band)|Oasis]] | country = United States | first_aired = January 9, 2006 | last_aired = Present | num_episodes = | website = [http://www.siriusxm.com/howard100 www.siriusxm.com/howard100] | podcast = }} '''''The Howard Stern Wrap-Up Show''''' (commonly just called '''''The Wrap-Up Show''''') is a radio show that follows ''[[The Howard Stern Show]]'' on [[Howard 100]], an uncensored channel on [[Sirius XM Radio]]. Hosted by [[Jon Hein]] and Executive producer [[Gary Dell'Abate]], the show discusses everything that happened on that day's Stern Show with listeners and various celebrity guests. Because ''The Howard Stern Show'' is contractually bound to broadcast a minimum of four hours on Sirius XM, there is no set time when the show ends, or effectively when ''The Howard Stern Wrap-Up Show'' begins. Regardless, ''The Howard Stern Wrap-Up Show'' always follows the main show and broadcasts for about an hour. Prior to 2015, ''The Howard Stern Wrap-Up Show'' was open for all show staff members to discuss topics along with Hein and Dell'Abate; however, the show now only features the hosts and a revolving panel of guests discussing ''The Howard Stern Show'' and each guest's respective promotions.{{cite web|title=HOWARD 100 & 101|url=https://www.howardstern.com/howard101/|website=HowardStern.com|accessdate=23 August 2015}} ==See also== * [[Howard Stern]] * ''[[The Howard Stern Show]]'' * [[Sirius XM Radio]] * [[Howard 100 and Howard 101|Howard 100]] ==References== ==External links== * [http://www.howard100channelguide.com/ Howard 100 Channel Guide] * [http://www.howardstern.com ''The Howard Stern Show'' Official Website] {{Howard_Stern_Show}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wrap-Up Show}} [[Category:American comedy radio programs]] [[Category:Sirius Satellite Radio]] [[Category:American radio programs]] [[Category:Howard Stern]] [[Category:2006 radio programme debuts]] {{US-radio-show-stub}}

revision.text:
{{More footnotes|date=April 2009}} {{Infobox anthem |title = |transcription = Walla Zaman Ya Selahy |english_title = Oh My Weapon |image = |image_size = |caption = |prefix = National |country = the {{flagdeco|Syria}} [[United Arab Republic]] ---- '''Former national anthem of {{flagdeco|Egypt|1972}} [[Egypt]] ---- '''Former national anthem of {{flagdeco|Iraq|1963}} [[Iraqi Republic (1958–68)|Iraq]] |author = [[Salah Jahin]] |lyrics_date = |composer = [[Kamal Al Taweel]] |music_date = |adopted = (by United Arab Republic) 1960
(by Egypt) 1971
(by Iraq) 1965 |until = (by United Arab Republic) 1971
(by Egypt) 1979
(by Iraq) 1981 |sound = |sound_title = }} "'''Walla Zaman Ya Selahy'''" ({{Lang-ar|والله زمان يا سلاحي}}) was the [[national anthem]] of the [[United Arab Republic]] (UAR), a federation of [[Egypt]] and [[Syria]], from 1960. Though the UAR broke up in 1961, Egypt retained the official name of the union until 1971, and the official anthem until 1979. ==History== {{National anthems of Iraq}} Prior to being adopted as the UAR anthem, it was a nationalist song performed by [[Umm Kulthum]] during the [[Suez Crisis]] in 1956, known in Egypt and the [[Arab world]] as the Tripartite Aggression, when Egypt was invaded by the [[United Kingdom]], [[France]], and [[Israel]]. Due to its strongly nationalist lyrics evoking national resistance, the song was played frequently on Egyptian radio during the war, sometimes as often as every 10 minutes. The popularity of the song led to it being adopted as the national anthem of the UAR two years after the establishment of the union. It replaced the former Egyptian anthem, "[[Nashid al-Huriyya]]" (''The Anthem of Liberty'', نشيد الحرية, composed and sung by [[Mohammed Abdel Wahab]]), which was adopted following the [[Egyptian revolution of 1952]] and the abolition of the monarchy, as well as the former [[national anthem of Syria]]. The lyrics were written by [[Salah Jahin]], with music by [[Kamal Al Taweel]]. The anthem was also used, without words, by [[Iraq]] from 1965 to 1981. It was eventually replaced in 1979 for the peace negotiations with Israel by President Sadate as Egypt's national anthem by the less militant "[[Bilady, Bilady, Bilady]]", which continues to be Egypt's anthem today.[https://books.google.be/books?hl=nl&id=h05vgm9bZkYC&q=menachim#v=snippet&q=menachim&f=false Virginia Danielson, "The Voice of Egypt": Umm Kulthum, Arabic Song, and Egyptian Society in the Twentieth Century (Chicago Studies in Ethnomusicology), p. 243] ==Lyrics== {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" ! Arabic Lyrics ! Transliteration ! Translation |- | style="text-align: right" lang="ar" | والله زمــان يـا سـلاحـي اشتـقـت لـك في كـفـاحي انطق وقـول أنـا صاحـي يــا حــرب والله زمــان والله زمـان ع الجــنــود زاحفة بـتـرعـد رعـود حالـفة تـروح لم تـعـود إلا بـنـصــر الـزمــان همـوا وضـمـوا الصـفـوف شيلوا الحياة ع الكفوف ياما العدو راح يـشـوف منكـم في نـار المـيـدان يـا مجـدنـا يـا مجـدنـا يا اللي اتبنـيت من عندنا بـشـقــانـا وكــدنــا عـمـرك مـا تبقى هـوان مصر الحرة مين يحميهــــا نحـميهـا بـسلاحـنـــا أرض الثورة مين يفديهـا نفـديها بأرواحـنــا الشعب بيزحـف زى النور الشعب جبال الشعـب بحور بركان غضبان بركان بيفور زلزال بيـشق لهم في قبور || Walla Zaman Ya Silahi Ishtaqti Lak Fi Kifahi Intaq We Qul Ana Sahi Ya Harb Walla Zaman. Walla Zaman 'Algunud Zahfa Bitir'id Ri'ud Halfa Tiruh Lam Ti'ud Illa Binasr Al-zaman. Hummu Wu Dummu Al-sufuf Shilu Al-hayat 'Alkufuf Yama Al-'adu Rah Yishuf Minkum Binar El-midan. Ya Magdina Ya Magdina Yalli Itbanait 'Andana Bishaqana Wa Kaddina 'Umrak Ma Tibqa Hawan. Masr Al-hurra Min Yihmiha Nihmiha Bislahna Ardh Al-thawra Min Yifdiha Nifdiha Biarwahna. Al-sha'b Biyizhaf Zayy El-nur Al-sha'b Gebal Al-sha'b Bhur Burkan Ghadban Burkan Biyfur Zilzal Biyshuqq Lohom Fi Qbur. || It has been a long time oh my weapon! I long for you in my struggle! Speak and say I am awake, Oh war it has been a long time. It has been a long time for the soldiers, Advancing with thunderous roar, Swearing never to return, Except with epoch-making victory. Rise and close ranks, With lives ready for sacrifice. O! the horror that the enemy shall suffer, From you in the fire of the battlefield. O! glory our glory, You who was built by us, By toil and pain, Never to go to waste. Who shall protect Free Egypt? We shall protect her with our weapons. Land of the Revolution, who will sacrifice for her sake? We will, with our souls. The people advance like the light, The people stand like mountains and seas, Volcanoes of anger, volcanoes erupting, Earthquakes digging the enemy into their graves. |} ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.nationalanthems.info/eg-79.htm Information, Audio, Lyrics, and Sheet Music on Walla Zaman Ya Selahy] {{nationalanthemsofasia}} [[Category:Anthems of Egypt]] [[Category:Historical national anthems]] [[Category:United Arab Republic]] [[Category:African anthems]] [[Category:Asian anthems]] [[Category:1960 songs]] {{anthem-stub}} {{Egypt-stub}}
